node.title: Would-be homebuyers ‘stuck in a dead-end road’ and renewed migration is likely to push prices even higher
node.alt: Sid Lal looks at a for sale sign in suburban Sydney in November 2021.
node.description: When Australia opens its borders to migrants to help in the post-COVID recovery, already skyrocketing house prices could further lift. One economist predicts the cost of buying a home will jump 5 per cent and rents will rise 7 per cent.
node.content:
["When Australia opens its borders to migrants, already skyrocketing house prices could rise further.", "While immigration is not the only factor influencing house prices, it adds to the already strong demand for housing.", "Economists say about one extra home is required for every three migrants.", "If Australia's annual immigration intake lifts, beyond federal budget forecasts, to reach about 250,000 people in 2023, that would turn predictions of house price falls into price gains.", "", "
AMP Capital chief economist Shane Oliver predicts house prices\u00a0will rise in 2023 by 5 per cent and rents by 7 per cent off the back of rapidly\u00a0rising migration.(John Gunn.)
", "Dr Oliver says much will depend on how high the annual immigration intake is, as well as other variables such as interest rates and the possibility of further restrictions on borrowing.", "But if the scenario of 250,000 migrants by 2023 eventuates \u2013 and given recent calls from political leaders for a \"Big Australia\" driven by immigration, that's entirely possible \u2014 he says house prices would jump about 5 per cent by 2023\u00a0and rents would lift about 7 per cent.", "Economists including Dr Oliver and the property industry have been once again calling on governments to increase housing stock to keep up with rising demand.", "But is that enough to keep the lid on house prices?", "
Migrants help grow the economy but also compete\u00a0for homes
", "For those who migrated pre-COVID, building more housing seems a worthwhile option.", "Poornima Balasubramanian made the move from Singapore to Melbourne with her husband Harish and daughter Adwitiya almost four years ago.", "", "
Poornima Balasubramanian and Harish Ganapathy are looking to buy a house in Melbourne.(Supplied.)
", "She came on a temporary student visa but is now working as a kindergarten teacher.", "She is in the final stages of becoming a permanent resident and is looking to move away from renting to homeownership.", "But buying a home in Glen Waverley, in the eastern suburbs of Melbourne where they currently rent, is proving tricky.", "\"I'm finding the process frustrating,\" she says.", "In Sydney's hot housing market, former migrant now Australian citizen, Sid Lal, has looked at hundreds of properties but is also struggling to find one.", "", "
Sid Lal\u00a0says the family are having to extend their budget significantly to be able to afford a home in Sydney.(Daniel Irvine.)
", "\"We are having to extend our budget significantly because you know what was available a year ago at the price point has now gone up by, I would say, easily 20 per cent,\" he says.", "Like most migrants who come here to work or study, he also rented for the first four years. Now Sid wants to buy a permanent home.", "\"We're very aware of the fact that migration's going to open back up,\" he says.", "
COVID saw people move to the regions, but most still want to live in inner city areas
", "BIS Oxford Economics chief economist Sarah Hunter says while COVID has caused peoples preferences about where they live to slightly shift, with some opting for regional locations, demand for housing in the inner-city areas of Melbourne and Sydney remains high.", "", "
BIS Oxford Economics chief economist Sarah Hunter says demand for housing in the inner-city areas of Melbourne and Sydney remains high.(John Gunn.)
", "She and other economists worry that once migrants return demand in those areas, as well as other major capital cities, may outweigh supply.", "A federal inquiry is currently looking at the issue of housing affordability and is considering options like building more homes and fast-tracking development approvals.", "One of the ways to keep prices within the reach of Australians would be to build more properties, but the Reserve Bank has said it's not the panacea to greater affordability.", "Nevertheless, while the Reserve Bank argues the supply of homes has kept up with population growth, it does note that finding land in inner-city areas where most people want to live is still a challenge.", "Dr Hunter says that off the back of population growth, the cost of renting will increase by 2023, and that will feed into higher house prices.", "
Calls to boost the supply of housing where people want to live\u00a0
", "The Urban Taskforce, which represents property developers, supports calls by some politicians for a higher migrant intake.", "Its chief executive\u00a0Tom Forrest says migrants will help Australia's post-COVID recovery, but that the policy needs to be supported by changes to the planning system that will also enable housing supply to meet that level.", "", "
Urban Taskforce chief executive Tom Forrest says increasing housing supply will help affordability.\u00a0(John Gunn.)
", "\"Every treasurer will tell you that the major stimulus for economic growth \u2014 the way that you get taxation receipts up, and therefore you're able to pay for the costs of health care for the ageing demographic \u2014 \u2026 is through increasing migration,\" he says.", "Dr Oliver agrees: \"To solve this problem of poor affordability we need more supply,\" he says.", "\"Yes, supply has kept up with supply over the last few years, but that was after a decade of undersupply relative to demand,\" he says.", "\"And all we've really done is perhaps get back close to balance.\"", "Ms Balasubramanian wants the country to embrace migrants but also support any moves that would make housing more affordable.", "", "
Harish Ganapathy, 41, Adwitiya Harish, 7, Poornima Balasubramanian, 39. The family came to Australia as migrants and are now looking to stay and buy a home.(Supplied.\u00a0)
", "\"Bringing migrants in is going to help us in so many ways, I mean, it's going to boost the economy, it's going to help with the universities, which is one of the main source of income in the state of Victoria,\" she says.", "But she also dreads a future with more competition for housing.", "\"We're just not able to figure out where we're going to get the funds for [a new home],\" she says.", "\"We're sort of stuck in like a dead-end road. And we're just hoping that some path is going to open up.\"", "That's a hope others share, as the great Australian dream of homeownership gets further out of reach for many."]
